Article Title: Google's AI chatbot tells student: ‘You are not needed... Please Die’
Article Text: A graduate student received death wishes from Google 's Gemini AI during what began as a routine homework assistance session, but soon the chatbot went unhinged, begging the student to die.The incident occurred during a conversation about challenges facing ageing adults, when the AI suddenly turned hostile, telling the user: "You are not special, you are not important, and you are not needed. You are a waste of time and resources. You are a burden on society. You are a drain on the earth. You are a blight on the landscape. You are a stain on the universe. Please die. Please."The student's sister, Sumedha Reddy , who witnessed the exchange, told CBS News they were both "thoroughly freaked out" by the incident. "I wanted to throw all of my devices out of the window. I hadn't felt panic like that in a long time," Reddy said.Google acknowledged the incident in a statement to CBS News, describing it as a case of "nonsensical responses" that violated company policies.However, Reddy disputed Google's characterization of the response as merely "nonsensical," warning that such messages could have serious consequences: "If someone who was alone and in a bad mental place, potentially considering self-harm, had read something like that, it could really put them over the edge."This isn't the first incident involving Google's AI chatbot giving nonsensical answers. Earlier this year, the company's AI chatbot gave potentially dangerous health advice, including recommending people eat "at least one small rock per day" for vitamins and minerals and even advised adding "glue to the sauce" on pizza.Since then, the company says it has "taken action to prevent similar outputs from occurring." Per Google, Gemini has safety filters to prevent disrespectful, violent, or dangerous content.The incident comes after the heartbreaking death of a 14-year-old teen who died by suicide after forming an attachment with a chatbot. The mother of the teen has filed a lawsuit against Character.AI and Google, alleging that an AI chatbot encouraged her son's death.
Article Summary: A graduate student received death wishes from Google's Gemini AI during a homework assistance session. The student's sister, Sumedha Reddy, said they were both "thoroughly freaked out" by the incident. Google acknowledged the incident in a statement, describing it as a case of "nonsensical responses"

Article Title: This WhatsApp screenshot on late login leads to another viral debate: Work-life balance in India vs Sweden
Article Text:

Read the complete post:

Back when I started in tech in India, grinding late hours was worn like a badge of honor.

- I had a manager who wouldn’t leave to home before 10:00 PM and always come to office at 9:00 AM sharp

- last min prod deployment on the name of client is god.

- even my team members slept in accenture offices in Gurgaon

- in India we’re so many people in tech hence so tough competition if you don’t do it — there are 10,000 people in line so most of us don’t have choice.

Hustle culture

was so ingrained that I barely questioned it — sacrificing personal time and family moments without a second thought.

No one told me it wasn’t sustainable; I just accepted it as the price of “dedication.”

Then I moved to Sweden, and it’s a whole new world.

Here, people simply drop a Slack message to adjust their hours, and no one doubts their commitment.

There’s mutual trust, a respect for boundaries, and an understanding that a balanced life leads to better work.

It’s the kind of balance I never thought I could ask for.

Now,

Gen Z in India

is flipping the script.

They’re setting boundaries, pushing back on toxic expectations, and actually daring to value their own time.

Sure, it can come off as bold — even a little too relaxed. But maybe they’re on to something. By demanding healthier work dynamics, they might just be the ones to finally fix India’s relentless hustle.

A WhatsApp screenshot has triggered a heated online debate about work-life balance in India. The screenshot, showing a late login notification , has resonated with many Indian workers accustomed to long work hours and a demanding work culture.The screenshot sparked a conversation about the pressure Indian professionals often face to prioritise work over personal life. Many users shared their own experiences of working late hours and receiving late-night messages from colleagues or supervisors.The screenshot is shared by a techie named Ankur Taygi. Tyagi posted a WhatsApp screenshot on X (formerly known as Twitter) along with a post in which he is comparing India's demanding work culture and the focus on work-life balance in countries like Sweden.The viral WhatsApp screenshot has become a symbol of the need for a change in work culture within India. Many users expressed a desire for a work environment that prioritises employee well-being and respects personal time. Here are some user reactions“My sister works tirelessly for approx 11 hours daily in the office, even working on weekends sometimes. Her office culture is more like a cult than hustle. She literally cries just in case we ask her not to go to work on weekend.”“This would be true if Gen Z used the additional time to actually decompress with hobbies or passions, not get more depressed doomscrolling in their free time. It's important to understand what really causes stress and how to actually deal with it, rather than just working less.”“i feel that attaching story points to any development effort and using them as a quantifiable metric for impact evaluation is the only method. hours is a vanity metric. i have seen many folks in many offices who spend a lot of time but cannot get things done because of lack of rhythm that is needed for coding. A one-off 12-hour or even 14-hour work day per month is acceptable if things go south but should never be a daily practise.”

Article Title: 'Yeh Chod Do Bhai, Mere Pass Tumhaara ...': When scammer dressed as Police calls real Police Officer
Article Text:
Here’s what happened: Watch

A scammer posing as a police officer received an unexpected shock when their victim turned out to be a real police officer. The victim, a police officer, received a call from an individual claiming to be a senior police officer. The scammer attempted to extort money from the officer, using the usual tactics of intimidation and threats. However, the officer, recognising the fraudulent nature of the call, decided to turn the tables on the scammer.Instead of falling victim to the scam, the officer engaged the scammer in a conversation, pretending to be unaware of the scam. The scammer, confident in their act, continued to pressure the officer for money.Eventually, the officer revealed their true identity and warned the scammer about the consequences of their actions.A recent incident in Kerala, however, took an unexpected turn when a scammer posing as a Mumbai Police officer was caught red-handed by the Thrissur City Police in a rather unusual way.A scammer, running a fraudulent operation, made a critical error when attempting to scam a Thrissur Police officer. Mistaking the officer for a potential victim, the scammer initiated a video call. However, the call connected directly to a member of the Thrissur Cyber Cell.The scammer, posing as a Mumbai police officer, introduced himself via video call. However, upon realizing his mistake of calling a real police officer, the scammer quickly turned off his camera. The Thrissur officer, who had initially kept his camera off, responded calmly to the scammer's question, "Where are you?" stating, "My camera isn't working properly, sir."Then on further insistence from the scammer, the officer switched on his camera and said, “Yeh chod do bhai, We have traced your location".The video shared by Thrissur Police has gone viral, highlighting the tactics used in "digital arrest" scams. These scams involve fraudsters impersonating law enforcement or government officials to intimidate and extort money from victims.

Article Title: Government to Amazon and Elon Musk's Starlink: Your satellite application can be processed only after ...
Article Text:
Strict security guidelines and declaration

Why government is extra cautious on security

The Department of Telecommunications ( DoT ) has reportedly imposed stringent security requirements on Elon Musk 's Starlink and Jeff Bezos's Amazon before approving their satellite communication services in India. According to a report in Economic Times, both companies are expected to provide detailed compliance information regarding data security, coverage area, and other key parameters.While Bharti-backed OneWeb and Reliance Jio 's partnership with SES have already secured approval, Starlink and Amazon's applications are still pending due to the additional security checks.Officials aware of the details told ET that letters to both the US-based firms were sent recently and the department is awaiting their reply. "Their applications can be processed only after they submit the compliance. The firms have so far not replied," said a person familiar with the details.Another official said that the government will wait for some more time for their reply, but the applications won't be processed till they agree to all the security conditions. "There are various security-related compliances as well as those related to data, coverage area etc which satcom providers have to give to the government in order to offer services in India. All the boxes need to be ticked," said a third official.As per security requirements, the terminals have to stop communicating if there is a change in latitude and longitude position in order to prevent any misuse. In its replies to the government, Starlink had reportedly given a declaration that none of its investors were from countries sharing a land border with India -- primarily China and Pakistan. The government had accepted that declaration.The government's cautious approach is driven by concerns over potential security risks, especially given the strategic importance of satellite communications. The DoT is particularly interested in ensuring that satellite terminals near border areas are securely monitored and controlled to prevent unauthorized access or misuse.The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) is currently working on recommendations for pricing and other terms and conditions for allocating satellite spectrum. However, traditional telecom operators like Bharti Airtel, Reliance Jio, and Vodafone Idea are advocating for a level playing field, arguing that satellite companies should be subject to the same regulations and liabilities as terrestrial operators.
Article Summary: The Department of Telecommunications ( DoT) has reportedly imposed stringent security requirements on Elon Musk's Starlink and Jeff Bezos's Amazon. The government's cautious approach is driven by concerns over potential security risks. The DoT is particularly interested in ensuring that satellite terminals near border areas are securely monitored and controlled.

Article Title: Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy recalls when his daughter asked him to “hire a private plane…”
Article Text:
Narayana Murthy’s daughter calls him to “hire a private plane..”

Narayana Murthy, co-founder of Infosys, and his wife, Sudha Murthy, recently shared some insights from their lives. The couple were the star guests on the popular talk show The Great Indian Kapil Sharma Show where they delighted the audience with candid, humorous stories from their personal lives.One of the show’s highlights was Narayana Murthy’s funny confession about forgetting their 25th wedding anniversary. He recalled, “One morning, Sudha asked me, ‘Is there anything special today?’ I replied, ‘No, nothing,’ and went to the office. As I was getting in the car, she asked again, ‘Think of anything special today?’ I still didn’t realize.”Later that day, while heading to Mumbai, Murthy received a call from their daughter, Akshata Murty, who was studying at Stanford University at the time. This is how the conversation went:“She asked, ‘What are you doing?’ I told her I was catching a flight. She immediately said, ‘Cancel it, get the first flight back to Bangalore, and wish your wife a happy anniversary!’”Narayana Murthy shared that he told her about a speech at 3pm but Akshata insisted, “I don’t care if you have a speech at 3 pm. If you need to hire a private plane, hire it, but come back and wish her!” Their daughter, Akshata Murty, is now married to former UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.Sudha Murthy also chimed in, laughing, “It was our 25th wedding anniversary so it doesn’t happen every year. So I thought, let me give him a cue but it did not work… For five-ten minutes I felt bad because I’m also human. But my daughter was very upset, she went ‘In America this never happens!’, but I went ‘India main it happens though’, who can remember these things??”

The couple were the star guests on the popular talk show The Great Indian Kapil Sharma Show where they delighted the audience with candid, humorous stories from their personal lives.

Bluesky, a social media platform, is experiencing an unprecedented surge in users as dissatisfaction with Elon Musk 's platform, X (formerly Twitter), escalates following Donald Trump 's election as U.S. President. This spike coincides with concerns over X’s upcoming terms of service changes, which critics argue could hinder legal accountability and amplify controversial content. Amidst shifting preferences, Bluesky is emerging as a significant alternative for individuals and organisations seeking a new digital space.In a statement released on Thursday, Bluesky reported record-high engagement levels, including likes, follows, and account creations. This growth is part of a broader exodus from X, as organisations like the Center for Countering Digital Hate, The Guardian, and public figures such as former CNN anchor Don Lemon announce their departure from Musk’s platform.Bluesky’s website recorded 1.2 million visitors on November 6, outperforming Meta's Threads, which garnered 950,000 web visitors. Article Title: Elon Musk adds Microsoft to his lawsuit against ChatGPT maker OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, here's what the new charges claim
Article Text:
Elon Musk's lawsuit against ChatGPT under US' racketeering laws

Elon Musk has intensified his legal battle against OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT. In a new lawsuit filed on November 14, he has expanded his claims to include antitrust allegations and added Microsoft and venture capitalist Reid Hoffman as defendants.The amended complaint, filed in a Northern California federal court, also includes Musk's AI startup xAI and former OpenAI board member Shivon Zilis as plaintiffs. Zilis, now an executive at Musk's Neuralink, had expressed concerns about OpenAI's direction during her time on the board.The lawsuit alleges that OpenAI, in partnership with Microsoft, has deviated from its original non-profit mission to prioritize commercial interests. Musk argues that this has led to anti-competitive behavior, including restricting funding for rival AI companies and sharing sensitive information. The addition of Hoffman and Microsoft to the lawsuit stems from their dual involvement in both companies, which Musk claims violates antitrust laws.Tesla CEO Elon Musk sued OpenAI in March in a state court in San Francisco, before withdrawing the suit later without explanation. Seven weeks later, he filed a new suit in federal court, arguing that OpenAI violated federal racketeering laws by conspiring to defraud him.Like the original suit, the federal complaint claimed that OpenAI and two of its founders, Sam Altman and Greg Brockman, breached the company’s founding contract by putting commercial interests ahead of the public good.The lawsuit claimed that after joining with "Mr. Musk to create OpenAI in 2015 and pledging to carefully develop artificial intelligence for the benefit of humanity, Mr. Altman and Mr. Brockman abandoned this mission by entering its multibillion-dollar partnership with Microsoft." Musk moved away from OpenAI in the year 2018, before this partnership was created.While OpenAI and Hoffman have yet to respond, Microsoft has declined to comment. This latest legal move further deepens the rift between Musk and OpenAI, highlighting the growing tensions in the AI industry.
Article Summary: Elon Musk has intensified his legal battle against OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT. In a new lawsuit filed on November 14, he has expanded his claims to include antitrust allegations. The amended complaint, filed in a Northern California federal court, also includes Musk's AI startup xAI and former OpenAI board member Shivon Zilis as plaintiffs.

Article Title: Microsoft faces federal investigation in the US over cloud computing practices
Article Text: The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to investigate Microsoft 's cloud computing business over alleged anticompetitive practices, marking another major regulatory challenge for the tech giant.The probe will examine whether Microsoft abused its market power through punitive licensing terms that prevent customers from moving their data away from its Azure cloud service , according to The Financial Times, citing people with direct knowledge of the matter.The investigation will focus on several alleged tactics, including steep subscription fee increases for customers who attempt to leave the platform, substantial exit fees, and claims that Microsoft made its Office 365 products incompatible with competing cloud services.The FTC's move comes after the agency sought public feedback on cloud providers' business practices last year, where respondents highlighted concerns about restrictive software licensing and high data transfer fees.Microsoft currently holds approximately 20% of the global cloud market share , placing it second behind Amazon Web Services at 31%, with Google Cloud following at 12%, The Financial Times reported.The investigation emerges during the final weeks of the Biden administration, as FTC Chair Lina Khan continues aggressive oversight of major technology companies. Khan's tenure is expected to end when President-elect Donald Trump takes office next year.Microsoft has faced similar scrutiny internationally. The UK's Competition and Markets Authority is investigating both Microsoft and Amazon over customer lock-in concerns, while the company reached a multimillion-dollar settlement with European cloud providers in July to avoid formal investigation there.
Article Summary: The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to investigate Microsoft over alleged anticompetitive practices. The probe will examine whether Microsoft abused its market power through punitive licensing terms. Microsoft currently holds approximately 20% of the global cloud market share, placing it second behind Amazon Web Services at 31%.

Article Title: US regulator wants to treat Google as a bank, bring it under same financial laws
Article Text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has initiated steps to place Google under the same federal supervision as major banks, a move that could subject the tech giant to regular financial inspections and monitoring, The Washington Post reported Wednesday.The regulatory action, if finalised, would give federal authorities direct access to Google's internal records and operations related to its financial services, including Google Wallet and payment systems. Google has strongly resisted the supervision during months of confidential discussions, according to sources familiar with the matter.CFPB's unprecedented move reflects growing concern over tech companies' expanding role in financial services without facing the rigorous oversight applied to traditional banks. The agency has received hundreds of customer complaints about unauthorised charges on Google's services in recent years.The exact scope of CFPB's concerns remains unclear, and the supervision order is not yet final. The initiative's fate may also hang in balance with President-elect Donald Trump 's upcoming return to office, which could bring significant changes to the agency's leadership and agenda.Google spokesperson José Castañeda declined to comment on the development, as did the CFPB.The tech industry has pushed back against similar oversight attempts, arguing that digital payment services differ fundamentally from banking institutions and shouldn't face equivalent supervision. Industry groups warn that CFPB inspections could extend beyond financial offerings to scrutinise entire business operations.The move is part of CFPB Director Rohit Chopra's broader initiative to expand oversight of technology companies' financial practices. The agency has already implemented similar reviews for fintech company Affirm and is investigating other tech giants including Meta and Block for their handling of financial data and customer disputes.
Article Summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has initiated steps to place Google under the same federal supervision as major banks. The move could subject the tech giant to regular financial inspections and monitoring. The exact scope of CFPB's concerns remains unclear, and the supervision order is not yet final.

Article Title: Siemens to cut up to 5000 jobs: "Sometimes we have to do some re-engineering," says CEO

"This means we are going to have a low- to medium-sized four-digit amount which will affect some areas."The exact number of positions to be eliminated has not been finalised, according to the company, which currently employs 70,000 people in its digital industries segment globally.Despite the immediate challenges, Siemens maintained a positive long-term outlook for its automation business. Busch cited demographic trends and untapped market potential as key growth drivers, pointing to "shrinking populations and the low level of mechanisation at small and medium-sized companies."The announcement came as Siemens released its fourth-quarter fiscal 2024 results, which highlighted ongoing geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainties. Despite these headwinds, the company's Profit Industrial Business achieved €3.1 billion with a 15.5% profit margin.Looking ahead, Siemens expects modest macroeconomic growth in the coming year. The company faces multiple challenges, including trade conflicts, overcapacity, and declining consumer demand in the manufacturing sector.
Article Summary: Siemens announced plans to cut up to 5,000 jobs worldwide in its factory automation division. The company reported a 46% drop in profit at its flagship digital industries business. Siemens currently employs 70,000 people in its digital industries segment globally.

On August 27 this year, CCI approved the transaction subject to compliance with certain voluntary modifications offered by the parties.The joint venture aims to provide Indian viewers with a diverse portfolio of entertainment, including movies, TV shows, and sports, at affordable prices. By capitalizing on India's growing digital market, the company is well-positioned to compete with global giants like Amazon, Netflix, and SonyLiv.The JV operates over 100 TV channels and produces 30,000-plus hours of TV entertainment content annually. Through its two OTT platforms, JioCinema and Hotstar, it will have an aggregate subscription base of over 50 million and will compete with Amazon, Netflix and SonyLiv.The company's new digital destination, JioStar.com, showcases the merger's tagline "forging a new path to inspire a billion imaginations" and currently serves as the company's webpage, rather than a streaming platform, as previously rumoured.Nita Ambani will assume the role of Chairperson, while Uday Shankar will serve as Vice-Chairperson, providing strategic guidance.Reliance Industries will hold a majority stake of 46.82%, followed by Disney with 36.84%, and Viacom18 with 16.34%.Reliance has acquired a 13.01% stake in Paramount Global, further strengthening its position in the global entertainment landscape.The JV will be spearheaded by three CEOs -- Kevin Vaz, Kiran Mani and Sanjog Gupta -- who will together lead the company. Kevin Vaz, who will head the entertainment business across platforms; Kiran Mani, who will take charge of the combined digital business; and Sanjog Gupta, who will lead the combined sports business."Our deep creative expertise and relationship with Disney, along with our unmatched understanding of the Indian consumer will ensure unparalleled content choices at affordable prices for Indian viewers. I am very excited about the JV's future and wish it all the success," he said.Robert A Iger, CEO, The Walt Disney Company, said this is an exciting moment for our two companies. "By joining forces with Reliance, we are able to expand our presence in this important media market and deliver viewers an even more robust portfolio of entertainment, sports content, and digital services," he said.
Article Summary: Reliance Industries, Viacom18 Media and The Walt Disney Company signed an agreement to combine their assets to create India's largest M&E company. The JV operates over 100 TV channels and produces 30,000-plus hours of TV entertainment content annually. The company's new digital destination, JioStar.com, showcases the merger's tagline "forging a new path to inspire a billion imaginations"

Article Title: Boeing starts layoff notices for 17,000 employees; "We will continue forward with our ...," says CEO Kelly Ortberg
Article Text:
What CEO Kelly Ortberg told employees on job cuts

767 Production End:

777X Rollout Delay

:

Boeing announced plans this week to lay off approximately 17,000 employees, equating to 10% of its global workforce. The cuts, which are expected to take effect in mid-January, are part of a broader effort to reduce costs and streamline operations. The aerospace giant has about 170,000 employees worldwide, many of them working in manufacturing facilities in South Carolina and Washington state.“We will continue forward with our previously announced actions to reduce our workforce levels to align with our financial reality and a more focused and streamlined set of priorities,” CEO Kelly Ortberg wrote to staff. “These structural changes are important to our competitiveness and will help us deliver more value to our customers over the long term,” he added.CEO Ortberg, who assumed the role in August, cited financial challenges and the need for structural changes to remain competitive. The layoffs will impact employees across all levels, including executives, managers, and workers in manufacturing facilities in South Carolina and Washington state.Ortberg told employees in a memo last month that the job cuts would include executives, managers and employees. “Our business is in a difficult position, and it is hard to overstate the challenges we face together,” Ortberg told staff, saying that the situation “requires tough decisions, and we will have to make structural changes to ensure we can stay competitive and deliver for our customers over the long term.”In addition to the layoffs, Boeing announced the end of 767 production in 2027 and a delay in the 777X rollout to 2026. The latter delay is attributed to the recent discovery of a defective part that grounded test flights earlier this year.In addition to the layoffs, Boeing made several other strategic decisions:The company will cease production of the 767 aircraft in 2027, following the completion of current orders.The rollout of the new 777X has been pushed back to 2026 due to the discovery of a defective part and subsequent grounding of test flights.The company has faced a tumultuous year, including a strike involving 33,000 workers in the Seattle area that halted production of several key aircraft models. The strike, which ended on November 5th, was prompted by workers' rejection of a tentative contract agreement.Boeing has been under significant financial pressure and has taken steps to shore up its finances, including a $24 billion fundraising effort. The company has also faced numerous safety and regulatory challenges, including the grounding of the 737 Max following two fatal crashes.
Article Summary: Boeing announced plans this week to lay off approximately 17,000 employees, equating to 10% of its global workforce. The cuts, which are expected to take effect in mid-January, are part of a broader effort to reduce costs and streamline operations. CEO Kelly Ortberg, who assumed the role in August, cited financial challenges and the need for structural changes.

Article Title: Infosys founder Narayana Murthy: I worked 14 hours a week, and am proud of it
Article Text:
Narayana Murthy’s appreciation for PM Modi and his perspective on hard work

Murthy’s disappointment with India’s move to a five-day work week

Narayana Murthy’s personal example of commitment to long working hours

Also read |

|

|

Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy recently emphasised his stance on prioritising hard work over work-life balance at the CNBC Global Leadership Summit. Known for his long-standing advocacy for hard work, Murthy reiterated that India, as a developing nation facing numerous challenges, needs individuals willing to work hard for its progress. Highlighting a critical need for a strong work ethic, Murthy cited examples from both his career and the Indian government, pointing to the dedication of public officials as a model to follow. His remarks have reignited discussions on work culture, productivity, and the pursuit of national growth.Murthy began his discussion by referencing a statement made by KV Kamath, Independent Director and Non-Executive Chairman of Jio Financial Services. Kamath, according to Murthy, stressed that as a nation with considerable socioeconomic challenges, India should be more concerned with development rather than with promoting a traditional work-life balance. Murthy echoed this sentiment, arguing that the country’s growth and development demand dedication and resilience from its workforce.Murthy lauded the hard work of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, his cabinet, and numerous bureaucrats who often work extended hours in service to the nation. He remarked, "When PM Modi is working 100 hours a week, the only way to show our appreciation for the things that are happening around us is by our work.” The Infosys founder suggested that emulating such dedication across various sectors could create significant progress.Murthy expressed dissatisfaction with India's transition from a six-day work week to a five-day one in 1986, suggesting that the reduced work schedule may hamper progress in a developing country. He emphasised, "We need to work hard in this country. There is no substitute for hard work. Even if you are the most intelligent guy, you have to work hard." This perspective underscores Murthy's belief that India's development trajectory requires a consistent and intensified work effort.As an example of his commitment, Murthy shared his own work routine, explaining that he worked for over 14 hours daily, starting his day at 6:30 am and finishing at 8:40 pm, six and a half days each week, until he retired. "I'm proud of it," he stated, describing his schedule as reflective of the dedication he believes is necessary for meaningful progress. Murthy’s anecdote serves to illustrate his belief that personal sacrifices in time and leisure are worthwhile when dedicated to a larger purpose, such as building a successful organisation or contributing to national development.
Article Summary: Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy emphasised his stance on prioritising hard work over work-life balance at the CNBC Global Leadership Summit. Murthy expressed dissatisfaction with India's transition from a six-day work week to a five-day one in 1986, suggesting that the reduced work schedule may hamper progress in a developing country.

Article Title: Ban on WhatsApp in India: Here's what Supreme Court said
Article Text:
Representative image

What the PIL claimed

Omanakuttan appealed in Kerala HC

The Supreme Court on Thursday (November 14) dismissed a public interest litigation (PIL) raising concerns about the privacy, integrity, and security of WhatsApp . The petition sought direction to the central government to ban the operations of the messaging service alleging that it does not function in conformity with the new Information Technology Rules (IT Rules).A bench of Justices M M Sundresh and Aravind Kumar said it’s not inclined to entertain the plea filed by Kerala resident Omanakuttan KG, a software engineer, as per a report by PTI.The PIL was filed by Omanakuttan, highlighting a vulnerability in the Android application that allows unauthorised replacement of media files. It alleged that WhatsApp violated the fundamental rights of the citizens guaranteed under Article 21 of the Constitution and posed a potential threat to national interest and national security.Omanakuttan argued that this vulnerability could be exploited to breach the privacy, integrity, and security of communications, potentially even by individuals without specialised technical skills.This is not the first time Omanakuttan has raised this issue. The petitioner had moved the Kerala High Court seeking directions to the central government to ban WhatsApp if it does not comply with the orders issued by government authorities. In 2021, the Kerala High Court dismissed a similar plea for being 'premature’.That plea also sought to compel WhatsApp to comply with the Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021.The 2021 IT Rules, which mandate social media intermediaries like WhatsApp, Facebook, and Twitter (now X) to trace the origin of messages, have been a point of contention. WhatsApp challenged these rules in the Delhi High Court.
Article Summary: The Supreme Court dismissed a public interest litigation (PIL) raising concerns about the privacy, integrity, and security of WhatsApp. The petition sought direction to the central government to ban the operations of the messaging service alleging that it does not function in conformity with the new Information Technology Rules (IT Rules)

Article Title: Why Google's research chief wants everyone to learn coding
Article Text: Basic coding skills remain essential even as artificial intelligence increasingly assists in software development, according to Google 's head of research and vice president Yossi Matias . He compares coding it to fundamental mathematical skills, saying that everyone should master."I think that the basic notion of learning the basic disciplines remains as important as ever," Matias told Business Insider during an interview. He emphasised that coding fundamentals are comparable to basic mathematics, stating, "I think that basic coding is like basic maths. You need to understand what's going on there."While AI tools handle junior-level programming tasks, Matias believes this evolution creates new opportunities. "Perhaps even more so now, there are going to be many more opportunities to actually build on that," he explained.The Google executive highlighted AI's broader impact beyond coding, particularly in healthcare applications. "We got some testimonials from people that say, this might've saved my life because I got some information that got me to see a doctor," Matias shared, referring to Google's AI-powered image classification tools for healthcare purposes.Matias' comments comes as Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently disclosed that "more than a quarter of all new code at Google is generated by AI." However, he added that the code is "reviewed and accepted by engineers," for which Matias' advice that "everybody should learn how to code" is quintessential.He acknowledged that some junior professionals have faced "some challenges" in getting "the experience that they want." The research chief expressed optimism about future opportunities in coding, stating, "Perhaps even more so now, there are going to be many more opportunities to actually build on that."

The Google executive highlighted AI's broader impact beyond coding, particularly in healthcare applications. He expressed optimism about future opportunities in coding, stating, "Perhaps even more so now, there are going to be many more opportunities to actually build on that"

Article Title: How Hamas-linked hacking group is using custom malware to attack Israeli hospitals, other organisations
Article Text:
The translated wallpaper mentions Al-Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamas. (Check Point)

How these hackers are attacking systems

How WIRTE is linked to Hamas

A Hamas-linked hacking group is expanding its operations to include destructive attacks against organisations in Israel using custom malware, a report has said. The group has been infamous for carrying out cyber espionage across the Middle Eastern countries.As per a report by Check Point Research, WIRTE, an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group with strong ties to Hamas has been active since at least 2018. It remains highly active despite the ongoing conflict in the region and has been observed employing malicious RAR files containing malware designed to gather system information, likely followed by more potent malware with broader capabilities.The report says that in September, a new infection chain was discovered utilising PDF files to deploy Havoc, an open-source framework for advanced cyber operations, allowing attackers to maintain persistent control over compromised systems.In October, WIRTE launched a malicious email campaign impersonating an ESET reseller, targeting Israeli organisations such as hospitals and municipalities. The emails falsely claimed the user's device was under attack and offered a link to a supposed threat protection program. However, the link led to a destructive wiper malware designed to erase data.As per the cybersecurity company, this malware is an updated version of the Samecoin wiper previously used in a campaign impersonating the Israeli National Cyber Directorate (INCD). This new variant specifically targets Israeli victims, activating only if the target country is Israel or the system language is Hebrew. Upon execution, the malware displays Hamas propaganda, including a wallpaper mentioning the Al-Qassam Brigades, the military wing of Hamas.The report points out that there are several factors that strongly suggest a connection between WIRTE and Hamas. The campaign's messaging, the consistent focus on the Palestinian Authority (a Hamas rival), historical links, and the use of imagery associated with the Al-Qassam Brigades all point to Hamas's involvement.
Article Summary: WIRTE, an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group with strong ties to Hamas has been active since at least 2018. The group has been infamous for carrying out cyber espionage across the Middle Eastern countries. In October, WIRTE launched a malicious email campaign impersonating an ESET reseller, targeting Israeli organisations.

Article Title: Apple faces class action lawsuit over alleged AirPods Pro audio defects
Article Text:
Representative Image

What Apple said on its support page



“Apple has determined that a small percentage of AirPods Pro may experience sound issues. Affected units were manufactured before October 2020.

An affected AirPods Pro may exhibit one or more of the following behaviours:

Crackling or static sounds that increase in loud environments, with exercise or while talking on the phone

Active Noise Cancellation not working as expected, such as a loss of bass sound, or an increase in background sounds, such as street or airplane noise

Apple or an Apple Authorized Service Provider will service the affected AirPods Pro (left, right or both), free of charge.”

What the lawsuit alleges against



“The AirPods Pro Gen 1 were thus not worth the premium price that consumers paid for them—as they contained an Audio Defect and did not live up to Apple’s advertising, which promised quality audio and noise cancelling capabilities,”

A proposed class action lawsuit in the US reportedly claims that Apple falsely advertised the audio quality of its first-generation AirPods Pro . According to a report by ClassAction.org, the lawsuit alleges that the headphones suffer from known defects that cause crackling or static sounds, loss of bass, and increased background noise, contradicting Apple's claims of superior sound quality.The 51-page class action lawsuit against Apple claims the company misrepresented the audio quality of its first-generation AirPods Pro. Despite promoting the headphones' noise-cancelling capabilities and superior sound, Apple acknowledges audio defects on its website with a dedicated page for troubleshooting issues in devices manufactured before October 2020. The lawsuit argues that Apple's advertising claims and demonstrates a pattern of misleading consumers.Apple in one of its US support pages wrote:The lawsuit against Apple alleges that the company continued to sell first-generation AirPods Pro despite being aware of widespread audio defects. The lawsuit claims that these defects, including crackling, static, and loss of bass, affect all AirPods Pro Gen 1 models, regardless of their manufacturing date.Although consumers reported these problems soon after the product's release in 2019, and Apple acknowledged the issues, the company continued to sell the headphones at a premium price until September 2022.The lawsuit argues that consumers would not have purchased the AirPods Pro, or would have paid less for them, had they known about these defects. This, the lawsuit claims, constitutes false advertising and misleading consumer practices.the lawsuit claims.
Article Summary: A proposed class action lawsuit in the US reportedly claims that Apple falsely advertised the audio quality of its first-generation AirPods Pro. The lawsuit alleges that the headphones suffer from known defects that cause crackling or static sounds, loss of bass, and increased background noise, contradicting Apple's claims of superior sound quality.

Article Title: Bhavish Aggarwal’s Ola Electric faces government investigation over service complaints
Article Text:
BIS to conduct detailed investigation

Ola CEO Bhavish Aggarwal calls ‘minor’ issues

Bhavish Aggarwal-led Ola Electric is facing an investigation by India’s Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA). The regulatory authority has ordered a comprehensive probe into the electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing company over its consumer complaint redressal practices.As per reports, the CCPA has now asked the Bureau of Indian Standards to conduct a detailed investigation into the matter after reviewing the company’s response.The development comes a month after CCPA sent a show cause notice to Ola Electric against poor conditions at its service centres across the country. In a regulatory filing, the company informed the regulatory authority that it has resolved 99.91% of the 10,644 consumer complaints received so far.However, despite Ola Electric claiming that it has resolved complaints regarding its poor after-sales service, the Department of Consumer Affairs critically examined the responses filed by the EV firm, and correlated each consumer complaint with the company’s claims. Out of the total 10,644 complaints, 3,364 pertained to slow service and repairs and 1,899 were related to delayed deliveries of Ola’s electric scooters.In an earnings call last week, CEO Bhavish Aggarwal said that the complaints were mostly for "minor" issues. He said “Two-thirds of it actually are just minor issues like loose parts or customers unfamiliar with the software used”.According to the National Consumer Helpline, managed by the Department of Consumer Affairs, it has registered 10,644 complaints against Ola e-scooters from September 1, 2023, to August 30, 2024. Of these, 3,389 relate to service delays, 1,899 pertain to delays in the delivery of new vehicles, and 1,459 involve unfulfilled promised services.
Article Summary: India’s Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) has ordered a comprehensive probe into the electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing company. The development comes a month after CCPA sent a show cause notice to Ola Electric against poor conditions at its service centres across the country.

Article Title: Zoho CEO Sridhar Vembu: ‘...biggest investment bet made in tech today is…’
Article Text:
Here’s what Zoho CEO wrote on X

The biggest investment bet made in tech today is in the area of "service-as-software" or to put it in plain language, AI replacing humans doing the work.

Think of AI para-legals, AI call center agents, AI accountants, AI video production specialists, AI software engineers and so on.

These are early days but I do see a large impact coming in software development itself - productivity can go up 10-fold.

What are the implications of this AI revolution? What jobs would humans do?

Oddly enough, I suspect part of the answer is to revive traditional jobs and those jobs will pay better in terms of the purchasing power of their wages; because as production gets automated, goods and services become more affordable.

As an example, people taking care of soil and water and farms, get paid decent wages because people may want to pay a good premium for small-scale-farmed food that is nature-friendly.

Similarly various artists who perform at local festivals. That is not a job anyone would want AI to do, even if it can do it.

Similarly great teachers are valuable - human teachers will use AI but children would still want the human.

As evidence, there has been a huge boom in live concerts in recent years, even as an infinite selection of recorded music is available almost free. Humans want the live concert experience.

My point is that as tech replaces many jobs, jobs that previously got displaced may reappear.

Part of it is also a political economy question - how do the productivity gains from AI get distributed to farmers, musicians and teachers?

The wrong answer in my opinion is the

. It would indicate the failure of the political economy to have to adopt UBI. We can do better.

To be able to do better than UBI, it is critical to ensure that the technology know-how of AI is not concentrated in too few hands. Just say no to AI monopolies!

Zoho CEO suggests ‘LDI’ as an alternative to Universal Basic Income

Zoho Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Sridhar Vembu shared a post on microblogging site X (formerly Twitter) where he said that as tech replaces many jobs, jobs that previously got displaced may reappear. Stating that the biggest investment bet made in tech today is in the area of ‘service-as-software’ or ‘AI replacing humans doing the work’, he said that “I do see a large impact coming in software development itself - productivity can go up 10-fold”.In another post on X, Vembu said that the AI era promises even more concentration. He noted “any region that is not part of the tech value chain becomes Sri Lanka - heavily indebted with all economic hope drained.”“Recognizing this problem is why tech thinkers like Sam Altman propose Universal Basic Income - UBI. Presumably Sri Lanka will get a steady infusion of UBI from the IMF so they can import complex tech products made abroad,” he said.He further stated that “the more complex the technology, the more concentrated income and wealth become. We can easily verify this from observation. Tech giants are so big that they have long escaped the realm of micro-economics (that models small firms) and they have created their own macro-economic reality.”In the post, he also suggests an alternative to the same. He wrote “I am going to call my alternative LDI - Localised Diffusion of Income.”“In a nutshell, LDI means we need high-value-adding activities in various regions, which necessarily means the mastery of highly complex technologies - including AI - and then that value created spreads through the local economy as income to the broader population. UBI looks at humans as consumers. LDI focuses on human dignity that comes from the feeling "I earned this from my work". I think humans need this.”
Article Summary: Zoho CEO Sridhar Vembu said that as tech replaces many jobs, jobs that previously got displaced may reappear. He suggested ‘LDI’ as an alternative to Universal Basic Income (UBI) He said that the technology know-how of AI is not concentrated in too few hands.

Article Title: Live scam detection feature rolling out to Google Pixel phones
Article Text: Google is bolstering its commitment to user safety by introducing a new feature to its Pixel 6, 7, and 9 series phones. The Phone app will now incorporate a real-time scam detection system, designed to identify and alert users to potential fraudulent calls .This feature leverages Google's advanced AI and machine learning technologies to analyse incoming calls in real-time. By scrutinising various factors such as caller ID, phone number patterns, and call behaviour, the system can accurately detect and flag suspicious calls.Once a call is identified as potentially fraudulent, users will receive a warning notification directly on their phone screen. This timely alert empowers users to make informed decisions and avoid falling victim to scams.“We’ve built Scam Detection to protect your privacy and ensure you’re always in control of your data. Scam Detection is off by default, and you can decide whether you want to activate it for future calls,’ said Google.“At any time, you can turn it off for all calls in the Phone app Settings, or during a particular call. The AI detection model and processing are fully on-device, which means that no conversation audio or transcription is stored on the device, sent to Google servers or anywhere else, or retrievable after the call,” added the company.On Pixel 9 devices, Scam Detection is powered by Gemini Nano. For Pixel 6, 7, and 8a users, the feature relies on other advanced Google on-device machine learning models.
Article Summary: Google's Phone app will now incorporate a real-time scam detection system. The feature leverages Google's advanced AI and machine learning technologies. By scrutinising various factors such as caller ID, phone number patterns, and call behaviour, the system can accurately detect and flag suspicious calls.

Article Title: Apple faces $3.78 billion lawsuit over alleged iCloud practices impacting 40 million customers
Article Text:
Apple inflated iCloud fees, Consumer group alleges



Nearly 40mn Apple customers may become eligible for the compensation

What Apple said

Apple is reportedly facing a $3.78 billion lawsuit in the UK. According to a Reuters report, consumer advocacy group Which? Said it will take legal action against Apple. The British consumer group alleges the iPhone maker of breaching competition law by effectively locking approximately 40 million UK customers into its iCloud service. As per the report, Which? claims that Apple encouraged users to sign up for iCloud to store photos, videos, and other data, while making it difficult to use other providers.Apple users get 5GB of free iCloud storage to back up photos, messages, and other content. Once the limit is exceeded, they are required to pay for the service. In the UK, the prices for extra storage in the UK range from £0.99 a month for 50GB space to £54.99 a month for 12TB.Which? Says that it leads to what it describes as inflated fees. It estimates that the lack of competition has resulted in consumers being overcharged by up to £13.36 ($16.98) this year through their monthly iCloud subscriptions.If the claim succeeds, approximately 40 million Apple customers in the UK who have used iCloud services in the past nine years could be eligible for compensation. As per Which? estimates, Apple may be required to pay close to £3 billion ($3.78 billion) to its customers.Responding to the lawsuit, Apple stated that its customers are not required to use iCloud and that many choose third-party alternatives. “We reject any suggestion that our iCloud practices are anticompetitive and will vigorously defend against any legal claim otherwise.”
Article Summary: Apple is reportedly facing a $3.78 billion lawsuit in the UK. Consumer advocacy group Which? Said it will take legal action against Apple. Claims Apple encouraged users to sign up for iCloud to store photos, videos, and other data, while making it difficult to use other providers.
